DataElement.preferredName: Image Exposure Micro Ampere 12 Byte Number
DataElement.preferredDefinition: The exposure expressed in uAs, for example calculated from Exposure Time and X-ray Tube Current.   [Standard-based]

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Any record of an imaging event whether physical or electronic._Contact with infectious agents (bacteria or viruses) in a manner that promotes transmission and increases the likelihood of disease. (CDC)_A prefix indicating a quantity of one one-millionth, 10E-6._One of the seven base units of the International System of Units (Systeme International d'Unites, SI), the unit of electric current, named after the French physicist Andre Ampere. It is that constant current which, if maintained in two straight parallel conductors of infinite length and zero diameter separated by one meter in a vacuum, would produce between these conductors a force equal to 2x10(e)7 newton per meter of length. This is dependent upon the definitions of the meter, kilogram, and second. One ampere represents 6.24 x 10(e+18) unit electric charge carriers, such as electrons, passing a specified fixed point in one second.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Any record of an imaging event whether physical or electronic.

Concepts.definition: Any record of an imaging event whether physical or electronic.

Property.preferredDefinition: Contact with infectious agents (bacteria or viruses) in a manner that promotes transmission and increases the likelihood of disease. (CDC):A prefix indicating a quantity of one one-millionth, 10E-6.:One of the seven base units of the International System of Units (Systeme International d'Unites, SI), the unit of electric current, named after the French physicist Andre Ampere. It is that constant current which, if maintained in two straight parallel conductors of infinite length and zero diameter separated by one meter in a vacuum, would produce between these conductors a force equal to 2x10(e)7 newton per meter of length. This is dependent upon the definitions of the meter, kilogram, and second. One ampere represents 6.24 x 10(e+18) unit electric charge carriers, such as electrons, passing a specified fixed point in one second.

Concepts.definition: The act of subjecting someone or something to an influencing experience.
A prefix indicating a quantity of one one-millionth, 10E-6.

A unit of electric current, one of the seven base units of the International System of Units (Systeme International d'Unites, SI). It is that constant current which, if maintained in two straight parallel conductors of infinite length and zero diameter separated by one meter in a vacuum, would produce between these conductors a force equal to 2x10E7 newton per meter of length. This is dependent upon the definitions of the meter, kilogram, and second. One ampere represents 6.24 x 10E18 unit electric charge carriers, such as electrons, passing a specified fixed point in one second.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Events, people, materials and activities uniquely defined by medical imaging.
ConceptualDomain.origin: DICOM:Digital Imaging and Communications in Medicine

DataElementConcept.origin: DICOM:Digital Imaging and Communications in Medicine
DataElementConcept.changeDescription: 10/22/08 - released post NCIA Interim Rpt Changes

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: IS: A string of characters representing an Integer in base-10 (decimal), shall contain only the listed characters (0-9, +,-). [Standard-based]

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the results of evaluations of the patient and the patient's disease.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: A number with no fractional part.::12:A sequence of 8 bits processed as a single unit of information.:Number; a concept of quantity derived from zero and units; a numeral or string of numerals that is used for identification.

Concepts.definition: A number with no fractional part, including the negative and positive numbers as well as zero.
A sequence of 8 bits processed as a single unit of information.
A numeral or string of numerals expressing value, quantity, or identification.
